div1.p: Consulat Général De L'État Indèpendant Du Congo. Baltimore.
MEMORANDUM ON THE CATHOLIC MOVEMENT IN FAVOR CONGO.

The "Congo Reform Association" has from the beginning, made its campaign on religious lines. Its agents here are all protestant ministers, they hold their meeting in churches and use the societies and organizations of these churches to gather petitions, to form committies and to carry on their propaganda. It is they who have made it a religious war and they have been trying to prevent the Catholic Church from realizing that they have declared war, while they know that the organization of the Catholic Church is the most powerful body that could oppose them. The Church has, however, been on guard for the past two years. In December, 1904, I was invited to attend a council of the most important dignitaries and laics of the Church to tell them the Congo situation and since that time they have stood ready to help us if the necessity should arise.

We had hoped to be able to manage the campaign alone without their open aid, and we could have done it not been for this unfortunate Kowalski-Wack affair. The scandal created by the publicaiton of that affair almost absolutely tied the hands of our friends in the Senate and created a predjudice against us in the minds of Senators who otherwise would have been indifferent or even friendly. Our enemies, taking advantage of the moment, were pushing the Lodge Resolution. The only thing to prevent the
Consulat Général De L'État Indépendant Du Congo. Baltimore.

adoption of that resolution was to bring some new and powerful force to our aid, and the most powerful organization available was our natural ally, the Church. Fortunately at that moment our enemies made the mistake of openly attacking the Cardinal Gibbons. That gave us an opening. The Cardinal replied to the attack by a strong defense of the King-Sovereign's administration. The statement was published all over the country and immediately had a good effect not only upon Catholics but also upon protestants, for the Cardinal is greatly admired and respected by all creeds. The newspapers referred to the Cardinal's utterance in their editorials and became more cautious and conservative in regard to intervention in the Congo. The statement had also undoubtedly a very favorable effect on the Government at Washington and we have reason to believe that since that statement appeared (post hoc ergo propter hoc) the President has taken a more favorable attitude. There is no doubt that the President and his party pay great heed to the opinion of the Cardinal and of the Catholic hoping to gain the political support of the Catholic vote.

The statement of the Cardinal was not enough, however. It motified the attitude of the Government, but according to the views of the most astute politicians among our friends, there was every probability that the Lodge Resolution would be adopted by the Senate Committee. The only card left for us to play (and it is the card most feared by our enemies) was the influence of the Catholic Church.

The Catholic Church represents to the American politician powerful factor in the politics and a great number of votes. It is the only thing to offset the numerous petitions coming into the Senate from small Baptists, Presbyterians and other churches which also represent votes to the politician. The politician is governed by fear of his electors. If he is petitioned by a number of his electors from small Baptist churches to meddle with the Congo he will be inclined to do it unless he is made aware that he will offend other voters. We had to make him aware of this. Calling to our aid the Catholic societies with their large membership of American voters was our only chance to restrain the Senate from rash action against us. It is well known in the United States that every politician is afraid to meddle with any question which may offend Catholic votes.
This step was thought a wise political move by our friends here who best understand the politics of this country. Baron
Consulat Général De L'État Indépendant Du Congo. Baltimore.

Moncheur and I cabled what steps we were about to take and received no objections form Brussels. I obtained the approval and support of the Highest dignitaries of the Church and then immediately started to set in motion our friends of the Catholic, Belgian and Irish societies throughout the country so that they might protest to the American Goverment against intervention in Congo affairs. Fortunately the Senate had adjourned for a holiday of two weeks at Christmas. This gave me time, by travelling night and day to cover several thousand mils of territory, to communicate with such men as Archbishop Messmer, Bishop McFaul, Bishop Fox, Bishop Maes, and about ten other Bishops besides laics of importance and also with the heads of various societies of laymen and with other organizations.

As a result there have been placed before the President and the Government and before the Senate (upon the reassembling of the Senate a few days ago) petitions in our favor from individuals and societies representing nearly two million American citizens urging the American Governemnt to refrain from any interference with the Congo.
As well as I can ascertain the following petitions representing the sentiments of nearly two million are by this time already before the Government and Congress:

AmiercanAmerican Federation of Catholic Societies representing 1,500,000 members Order of Foresters representing 125,000 members Catholic Knights of St. Louis Belgian Society of Chicago Belgian Protective Society of Denver Belgian Protective Society of New York Belgian Union of New York Belgian Beneficial Society of New York Several Catholic Societies of Rochester, State of New York. Individual letters from influential citizens, bishops, laics, &c. to the President, the Secretary of State and Senators. Petitions and protests from 700 or 800 citizens of Denver, New York, Rochester, Louisville and Philadelphia.
This expression of sentiment in our favor is now before the American Governement representing nearly two million American citizens.
Consulat Général De L'État Indépendant Du Congo. Baltimore.
In addition we expect that in the next few days there will reach the American Government the Senate petitions in our favor from:-

The Federation of the State of New York The Federation of the County of New York About 40 differeny socities in New York and Brooklyn About 400 or 500 individual citizens of New York About 200 or 300 citizens of Chicago Ancient Order of Hibernians representing 250,000 members Central Verein " 100,000 " Catholic BortherhoodBrotherhood of American " 65,000 " Catholic Knights of America " 20,000 " Western Catholic Union " 7,000 " Bohemian Catholic Union " 10,000 " Catholic Knights of Ladies of America " 8,000 " Women's Catholic Order " 50,000 " Irish Catholic Union " 10,000 " 44 Federation Societies in 44 different States"

The above societies are expected not only to petitions in favor of the Congo to the President, the Secretary of State and the Senate CommitteCommittee on Foreign Affairs but also to write to the Senators form their respective States.

This is a powerful movement we have started. It gives us the most powerful support we can have. It will not lose us any of our protestant supporters and it can cause no harm to any one except to the enemies of the Congo. Our Catholic support cannot in any way cause embarrassment to the American Government, if that Government is well disposed toward the Congo. it is possible that the American Government, if it wishes to meddle in the Congo, should have preferred that we shyould not make any resistance or any show of strength. If the American Government is well disposed toward us it will be glad to see us bring ourout all our forces for this will strengthen the American Governments hand against the anti-Congo agitators. The only real objection the American Government could have to such a demonstration is that (if it is illdisposed towards us) fear of the Catholic vote would prevent it from carrying out its intention and from taking on extremely hostile attitude towards us.
It will be observed that in all this movement I have kept in the background and made it appear that the Catholic movement was entirely spontaneous.
Consulat Général De L'État Indépendant Du Congo. Baltimore.

Our movement may not be entirely successful. We are working against great odds on account of the Kowalski-Wack affair. If we succeed it will be snatching victory out of defeat. In any case, even if the Lodge Resolution is adopted, the fact that we have Catholic support will undoubtedly prevent the American Governemtn from any extremely aggressive movement which it might wish to take.
James Gustavus Whiteley Seventh January.
